posts.name: Mark
posts.cooked:
Hi all,

I am a novice with electric motors and was curious how I could go about characterizing a brushed dc motor that I was planning to use for an rc lawn motor. I have two of these motors lying around without any kind of spec associated and was hoping to use them for the project. I really don‚Äôt have a speed requirement, more just enough torque to start moving and then plug along at whatever speed is possible.

At the end of the day, I‚Äôm trying to figure out what voltage to run my motor at, up to 40v (battery voltage on the lawnmower) to avoid burning it up. I also realize load and gear ratio play a big role in the current that will be drawn by the motors but I don‚Äôt know where to start to quantify this.

Any expertise to help fill the gaps in my knowledge would be awesome! Thanks very much!

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: First question: what markings are on the motors? Usually that will at least give a model number, if not the full power specs.

posts.name: Adam Reed
posts.cooked:
This typically requires the use of a dynamometer to measure the speed and torque of the motor while it is operating and then slowing the motor down to a stall to acquire the max current draw at your operating voltage. More can be found on this procedure on the VexPro motor website .

You can acquire some fairly basic information on your motor with the following.

With a handheld tachometer and a known voltage you can get the RPM of the motor, I‚Äôm not certain about regular DC motors but I know hobby motors are listed by KV (1000RPM/Volt) and you might be able to extrapolate from there to higher voltages.

You may not want to risk burning out your motor on this one but you might be able to get a snapshot of the peak current by locking the motor and shaft in a vice, turning it on, getting a quick read on the current and quickly turning it off before you release the blue smoke.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
A_Reed:

You may not want to risk burning out your motor on this one but you might be able to get a snapshot of the peak current by locking the motor and shaft in a vice, turning it on, getting a quick read on the current and quickly turning it off before you release the blue smoke.

Actually, it is easier and safer than this to get a decent estimate for stall current for a specific voltage.  At stall, a DC brushed motor is equivalent to a resistor.  Just get a multimeter and use it to measure resistance across the terminals/leads*.  I=V/R.

* If making this measurement actually causes the motor to spin, you‚Äôll have to find some way to lock the shaft.

@A_Reed ‚Äôs method for finding KV looks good - put in a low voltage with no load but a tachometer of some sort, subtract the voltage drop due to resistance, and use that to get a KV value.

Testing for a peak operating current is trickier, especially as you obviously don‚Äôt want to do destructive testing.  Fortunately, you have two supposedly equal motors.  I suggest that you build a mount for the motors so they have to rotate at the same speed.  You could put them face-to-face with a shaft coupler, or put them both as inputs to the same gearbox, with the same gear ratio on each motor.  On one motor, short the terminals, creating a ‚Äúbrake mode‚Äù.  On the other, apply a voltage you‚Äôre confident is below the maximum.  Use an IR thermometer to measure the temperature of the motor you‚Äôre driving for several minutes.  The best place to measure is going to be the output shaft (or a back shaft if it sticks out), because brushed motors generate their heat on the rotor.  Try again with increasing voltages until you find temperatures you are just barely comfortable with.  Personally, that‚Äôd be about 200¬∞F or 95¬∞C, your tolerance may vary.  The key thing is when you think the insulation inside the motor is or is not going to burn up [a.k.a. release the magic blue smoke].

Added later, obvously:

gerthworm:

Four wire resistance measurement techniques would be in order, most likely.

True, true.  You may also find useful info on this googling the Wheatstone Bridge.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
It‚Äôll be highly dependent on the quality of the multimeter - most hobbyist models stop being very accurate when you get down to small resistances.

For example, a CIM motor has a resistance of ~12/120 = 0.1 ohms. This isn‚Äôt much more than most test leads themselves - you‚Äôll need something expensive enough to have a few digits of precision down in that range.

Four wire resistance measurement techniques would be in order, most likely.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
Eric asked the right first question:  what information is printed on the motors?  A closely related one:  how big are they?  Diameter and length? Pictures will also help us to give useful advice virtually.

The second question:  what test equipment is available to you?
